Award.AwardTitle: Online Learning Forums for Improved Engineering Student Outcomes in Calculus

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is responding to urgent needs to graduate increased numbers of engineers by developing and evaluating an online calculus course for engineering students. Calculus is a critical course in the success of engineering students, and success rates need to be improved for this course.

This project is also producing new knowledge concerning the effectiveness of online learning forums as instructional interventions in engineering education. It is creating and disseminating usage guidelines to promote widespread use of online learning forums throughout STEM education, including K-12 and undergraduate settings.

This project is supporting a national need to rapidly increase opportunities for underrepresented student groups (geographically dispersed rural residents, working professionals, and women) to pursue engineering degrees via distance education. The numbers of nontraditional students now participating in distance engineering programs necessitates innovative instructional interventions to support them within these challenging new learning environments.

In sum, this project is seeking to 1) improve engineering student academic achievement in calculus, 2) increase engineering student interest in learning calculus and improving students' attitudes toward pursuing an engineering career, and 3) broaden the use of online learning forums throughout STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is argued that success in first year calculus is one of the most reliable indicators of student retention in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) degree programs. Research shows strong correlation between academic performance in first year calculus and ultimate attainment of an undergraduate STEM degree. In order to improve retention of undergraduates in STEM programs of study, advanced instructional strategies are needed to improve student academic achievement, engagement and attitudes towards learning in these early, foundational mathematics courses. And, as an increasing number of STEM degree programs incorporate hybrid and/or online course offerings, strategies that can be adapted for use in distributed and distance -delivered instruction as well as traditional classroom settings bear the greatest transformative potential.

The overall purpose of this exploratory research project, funded under the Transforming Undergraduate Education in STEM (TUES) program, was to implement and assess the effectiveness of an online, wiki-based learning forum during the first-year calculus sequence (i.e., Calculus I and II). In this study, calculus courses were offered in a distance-delivered (i.e., synchronous broadcast) format to students majoring in STEM disciplines at regional campuses of a western, land grant, public university. The assessment measured the extent to which the implementation of the online learning forum affected STEM student cognitive (academic achievement) and affective (engagement, attitudes) learning outcomes. Qualitative and quantitative data generated during the study were then used to develop an evidence-based, STEM undergraduate help seeking usage model, deriving from user-centered design principles, to promote and facilitate effective use of online learning forums within the larger STEM education community.

Intellectual Merit. This concurrent, embedded, mixed methods research study generated a rich set of qualitative and quantitative data related to the help-seeking attitudes and behaviors exhibited by the STEM undergraduate participants during first year calculus. The findings of this study are related to the implementation of online learning forums and the products of this study (i.e. usage model documents) are transferable across STEM disciplines and instructional delivery platforms (i.e., traditional, hybrid, synchronous broadcast and asynchronous online learning environments). Our data, findings, and products extend important areas of thought and research in STEM education including teacher and instructional change strategies, undergraduate resistance to active learning—particularly asynchronous, web-based interventions accessed out of class—and the transfer of STEM education research into STEM teaching practice.

Broader Impacts. Thus far, the results from this grant have been disseminated to researchers and STEM education practitioners through six publications in STEM and engineering education conference proceedings and 11 research presentations. The products of this study (i.e. help seeking usage model) support and facilitate the use online learning forums as active learning tools in calculus courses and more broadly in undergraduate STEM education. We expect the usage model to aid the transfer of evidence based instructional strategies through contextualized recommendations for implementing online learning forums within STEM courses. We anticipate that findings from this study will lead to changes in the ways that mathematics and other STEM courses are taught and supported. We envision web-based support interventions as one way for instructors to make higher education more accessible, interactive, and supportive to diverse, nontraditional students enrolled in STEM degree programs.
